citeinfo.origin: USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center and NBII
citeinfo.title: Breeding Bird Atlas Explorer
citeinfo.othercit: U.S. Geological Survey, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, 2011. Breeding Bird Atlas Explorer, provided by National Biological Information Infrastructure and USGS. Available online at http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bba. (Accessed <access date here>.)

descript.abstract: The Breeding Bird Atlas (BBA) Explorer is a website and data management system that offers data from published BBAs and interim data from ongoing BBAs in the United States in a uniform system. It allows users to learn about the methods used in each atlas project, to get species and block information for each project, and to view the results by species, block, or region in a table or map format. Most descriptive information and tabular results are available through each Atlas Home page and maps are available through our BBA Species Map tool. There are over 30 state datasets, and a dozen county-level atlas datasets, contained in the repository, but it does not contain all of the atlas projects in North American. The database housing these geospatial datasets contains more information on request, mostly metadata about methods and more detailed effort and observational data that may be useful in research. See our contact information for further information.Additional breeding bird atlas datasets can be obtained through Bird Studies Canada, which holds all of the Canadian atlas datasets, and the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, which houses several recent or current atlas projects through their website.
descript.purpose: The Breeding Bird Atlas (BBA) Explorer is a website and data management system that offers data from published BBAs and interim data from ongoing BBAs in the United States in a uniform system. Breeding bird atlases are avian distribution survey projects designed to cover large geographic areas using a grid based system and are generally organized at the state or provincial level.
descript.supplinf:
We attempt to provide this information in multiple formats. First, we provide web-based mapping that does not require the user to have GIS at all. These maps are available at the main URI.
Next we have provided shapefiles in the past, however we intend to move towards other formats: ESRI file geodatabases, and Web mapping services.

idinfo.useconst:
USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center's website and date of access should be cited in any use of this database (see Citation section).
Substantial use of any single atlas project's data in publication or reports should cite those individual projects as well (citation format on each relevant page); and we encourage users to seek out the print publications in this case as they provide more substantial information and interpretation of data and maps. For extensive use of atlas data in research publications, we welcome invitations of co-authorship, but it is not a requirement.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

idinfo.datacred: Thousands of volunteers in atlas project in over 30 states and a dozen counties collected the data for each breeding bird atlas project. Individual project sponsors are listed here: http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/bba/index.cfm?fa=bba.Sponsors. More details on each projects, and contact and source information for each (state or county) project is contained in the individual project datasets and metadata records. We compiled these datasets for use in a common system for access at USGS Patuxent Wildlife Research Center. Data compilers include Naoko Griffin, Allison Sussman, Anna Ott, Mark Wimer. The compiling of atlas datasets was supported primarily through funding from the National Biological Information Infrastructure, or NBII, Bird Conservation Node. Elizabeth Martin at NBII was central to the support of this database from 2001 to 2010.

dataqual.logic: Polygon consistency checked in ArcMap. (Topology validated.)
dataqual.complete: The state atlas datasets not archived in the repository are noted as such in the atlas projects table.

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at http://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html)

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey and National Biological Information Infrastructure

srctime.srccurr: Age of individual datasets varies (1970's to 2010's)

srcinfo.srccontr: See individual BBA dataset details for more information.

procstep.procdesc: Most of the time, we made several changes to an individual project dataset: updating species taxonomy to current day, reprojecting or re-creating spatial sampling grids. In a couple of cases, we re-typed the entire dataset from paper printouts to capture it digitally.

enttyp.enttypds: USGS and NBII Breeding Bird Atlas Explorer

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
Atlas survey project area - e.g. state or county name
Atlas projects are currently limited to the US and Canada
State, provincial, or county atlas
Name for the project, as it appears in BBA explorer; may include years or version
Brief project description
Atlases may be repeated over a long period; as of 2011, a dozen or more projects have started their 2nd version/round of surveys.
Whether published, or collecting data, and several other options
Numerical version of Status
State or province; usually same as Area Name, but not for county atlases
Start year of field work; most atlases cover the area over ~ 5 years
End of field sampling work
If the sponsoring organizations have a website, it is listed here
If a book or publication results, it is listed here
internal identifier used to link various tables - unique for each project
Date of book publication, if any
Survey blocks vary in size by project: many are 1/6th of a 7.5 minute topographic map, others are 10km sq for example
Further description of survey blocks
Populated areas may attempt to cover all survey blocks on the grid - others can only do a sample

codesetd.codesetn: Complete coverage to priority blocks, e.g. 1/6th

attr.attrdef: More description of sampling effort
If a public dataset is available, e.g. where we harvested it for the BBA Explorer repository
Also, if a project publishes maps on the web, in addition to maps we prepare
Citation information for the electronic copy in our repository
Person who coordinated the project's field effort
Current contact person, e.g. to obtain permissions for extensive use of data
Contact info for that responsible party
If a project has a specific policy for use, or requests a form, it is stated here

Project vary in how they handle certain types of evidence with respect to timing of migration. Some projects use 'safe dates' to say: migrants are done passing through, so a singing bird is on its territory

attrdomv.udom: Safe dates used, not used, or other text description of safe dates applied

attr.attrdef: Sponsoring organization(s) are listed
The total number of species for which breeding evidence was obtained; these numbers will change for projects underway
Explanation of species totals, if necessary; e.g. in some cases a book includes a species "believed to breed", where we may not include that in our total

If our database has all sightings recorded, we put that here; in some cases many species have mutliple sightings that are condensed for summary and mapping as the "highest level of confidence" for a given survey block
Total number of birds "confirmed" as breeding, with one of the breeding evidence types given more confidence
Average species breeding per block over the entire atlas area; will be small for starting projects
Number of blocks covering atlas area; depening on sampling goal, not all may have recorded sightings or effort
Number of blocks with data; equal to or less than the total number of block in Sum_ProjBlockCount
Number of blocks receiving coverage
Total number of participants officially recognized as participating in the field work - usually under-reported
Total number of hours reported (from book or database)

overview.eaover: Features are breeding bird atlas survey projects. Attributes are taken from printed publications associated with datasets, or from summarized dataset elements if appropriate.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the US Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate data set limitations, and to the corrsponding printed publications for detailed interpretation of the data. The USGS shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
metainfo.metuc: Breeding Bird Atlases (BBAs) have a number of biases in their data and resulting distribution maps. One is that survey coverage is not even across the entire grid; areas near cities often receive more coverage, for example.
